title: Jon Stewart leads profanity-filled tribute as Dave Chappelle awarded Mark Twain Humor prize
text:
Dave Chappelle, the politically-incorrect comedian unafraid to tackle tough subjects in his monologues, was awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor at the Kennedy Center Sunday night.

Chappelle, known for his profanity laced-monologues delivered while smoking a cigarette, was teased by his fellow comedians for his foul language and politically incorrect habit during the nearly two-hour tribute.

'I don't know of anybody who cares more deeply and anyone who gives less a f***,' Jon Stewart said.

Dave Chappelle was awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor

In his tribute, Jon Stewart recalled how he and Chappelle both worked at Comedy Central together in the 1990s

Sarah Silverman joked about Chappelle's use of the n-word in his monologues

'It's actually perfect you're getting the Mark Twain prize because you two both love to have the n-word in your masterpieces,' Sarah Silverman told him.

'He is willing to make fun of anybody - whether you're white or gay. End of list,' Michael Che, co-anchor of 'Weekend Update,' said. 'When we talk about honesty, we talk about not being afraid to tell people the truth about how we feel. Because that's the connect that comedians can have with people and nobody does it better than you - ever.'

And Chappelle acknowledged his reputation as he accepted the award, cigarette in mouth and obscenities flying.

'Hold on right here because I know they're going to edit some of this s*** out,' he said during his speech. The show, taped Sunday night, will air on PBS in January.

He then tossed down his cigarette, went up to the Mark Twain Award sitting on a stand on the stage, stood next to it, gave a big smile and said directly to the camera in a serious monotone: 'It's an honor, thank you.'

The audience gave him a standing ovation.

Chappelle, 46, was toasted by a host of friends, including his writing partner Neal Brennan, Common, Bradley Cooper, Tiffany Haddish, John Legend, Lorne Michaels, Mos Def, Michael Che, Aziz Ansari, Sarah Silverman, Morgan Freeman, Colin Jost, Kenan Thompson and Stewart.

The night was filled with laughter and applause as the comedians ribbed Chappelle about his quirky career decisions while praising him as an honest voice in the comedy world.

Chappelle used his time on stage to sing the praises of comedy as a profession and share his love for making people laugh.

'Stand up comedy is an incredibly American job. I don't think any other country could produce this many comedians. And unbeknownst to anyone in this audience, I don't think there's a opinion that exists in this country that is not represented in a comedy club by somebody. Each, everyone of you has a champion in the room,' he said.

'I love this job. It saved my life,' he said. 'There is something so true about this job, when done correctly.'

In a time when the media has been criticized and free speech has been under attack, Chappelle pointed out the importance of the first amendment.

'First Amendment is first for reason. Second Amendment is just in case the first one doesn't work out,' he pointed out. 'Look at me smoking indoors. I didn't ask anybody. I just did it. What are they going to do? Kick me out before I get the prize? I don't think so. It's call leverage.'

'We got let some air out,' he added. 'The country's getting a little tight. It doesn't feel like it's ever felt in my lifetime.'

Dave Chappelle with his family at the Kennedy Center - his mother Yvonne is at the far left and his wife Elaine is seated to Chappelle's right

Lorne Michaels recalled how he only wanted Chappelle to host the 'Saturday Night Live' that aired right after the 2016 election

Bradley Cooper brought his daughter to the show and praised Chappelle for making him a better man

And he paid tribute to his mother Yvonne, who was in the audience.

'You have no idea what I put this woman through,' he said of his mom.

He recalled that, as a teenager, she would drive him to comedy clubs and sit there until late in the night so he would have a chance to practice his monologues.

'How many of you here have ever heard your mother say: "P**** jokes were a little too much tonight son,"' he said as the audience roared in laughter.

Politics made a small, cameo appearance during the night as various comedians took the stage.

'I see the love and the joy and the laughter in this room, I can't help but wonder is this what s*** was like down there when Obama was president. Laughter and joy? Now you all just walk around like go f*** yourself,' Jon Stewart said after he walked out on stage.

Chappelle, known for his sharp observations of race and society made with a biting wit, has mocked topics ranging from President Donald Trump to the #MeToo in his humor.

President Trump was not at the ceremony. He and first lady Melania Trump were watching the Washington Nationals play the Houston Astros in Game Five of the World Series as Chappelle was roasted.

Chappelle is a local. He was born in Washington D.C., attended the city’s prestigious Duke Ellington School of the Arts, and filmed his first HBO special in the nation’s capital at the Warner Theater.

He shot to fame with satirical comedy sketch series 'The Chappelle's Show' but shocked Hollywood when he walked away from a lucrative $50 million deal to extend the program. Instead he took an extended trip to Africa and disappeared for nearly a decade.

But Chappelle gradually returned to performing stand-up and signed a multimillion-dollar deal with Netflix last year.

Speaker Nancy Pelosi attended the Mark Twain award

Congressman Adam Schiff and his wife Eve attended the show

His quirky career decisions were the subject of much of the night.

Stewart recalled how the two men worked together at Comedy Central in the 1990s - he as the host of 'The Daily Show' and Chappelle hosting his self-titled program.

Stewart reminded the audience that Chappelle turned down $50 million to do a third season of his show.

'It's at that moment I remember thinking: Comedy Central has $50 million,' he said and then collapsed to the stage in laughter, pounding his fists on the floor.

'These motherf*****s won't even let us have snacks,' he added.

'The courage it takes for a performer and an artist to stand up for who you know you are,' he said, is one of the many reasons 'we love and respect and admire this man.'

Lorne Michaels, executive producer of 'Saturday Night Live, recalled how he only wanted Chappelle to host the show that would air immediately after Election Day in November of 2016.

'Whichever way the election went, I knew I needed someone to explain what had just happened,' he said.

'There was resistance from the network for reasons to numerous to mention,' he said of his idea to have Chappelle lead the night.

But Chappelle ended up the host and delivered a profanity-filled monologue, in which he mocked the outrage among white Americans about the result.

He claimed he wasn’t that surprised Trump won.

‘I know the whites. You guys aren’t as full of surprised as you used to be. I think I speak for all of Black America when I say we are praying for Omarosa,’ Chappelle said. ‘But America has actually done it – we’ve elected an internet troll as our president.’

‘I’m gonna let the whites figure this out among themselves,’ he added.

And he pledged to give Trump a chance.

‘I'm wishing Donald Trump luck, and I'm going to give him a chance, and we, the historically disenfranchised, demand that he give us one too,’ he concluded.

For that monologue, Chappelle received an Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series.

But he later expressed regret for what he said, saying he ‘f*** up’ for giving Trump a chance.

Michaels said Sunday night he had no idea what Chappelle was going to say in his monologue.

'I had no idea what he was going to do. I like to think he did,' Michaels dead panned and then went on to praise Chappelle for his 'brilliant' take on the 2016 results.

Actor Aziz Ansari joked about how Chappelle talked him into trying psychedelic mushrooms

The rapper Common talked about Chappelle's love of music

John Legend paid tribute to Chappelle's work to help the people of Dayton, Ohio, after a mass shooting there earlier this year

Bradley Cooper, who worked with Chappelle in 'A Star is Born,' said he was glad he met the comedian before his daughter - who was there with him at the show - was born as he 'made me a better man.'

And he also mentioned Chappelle's famous 'Saturday Night Live' monologue, referencing a part where Chappelle talked about a party he had been to at the White House when Obama was president and he had looked out upon a sea of black faces - and Bradley Cooper.

'I'm still mad about SNL,' Cooper said. 'In the monologue, you did say you know you were at the White House, and you saw a sea of faces and there was one white guy and you were like, oh Bradley Cooper's here. We went together motherf*****. What are you talking about?'

Chappelle grew up in Yellow Springs, Ohio, just outside of Dayton, and he hosted a free benefit concert for the city in August after a mass shooting resulted in nine deaths and multiple injuries.

Stewart recalled how Chappelle called him and asked him to participate.

'I watched him help a city, heal a wound and replace it not just with love and with compassion but as we sat and watched Stevie Wonder sang and had the crowd growing crazy and reclaiming their city, he turned to me on stage and said 'this is their memory now.

John Legend, also from Ohio, recalled how Chappelle brought 'comfort after tragedy.'

Chappelle has gained a reputation for his willingness to sacrifice financial gain or order to remain artistically independent.

Morgan Freeman narrated the program

Dave Chappelle paid tribute to his love of comedy when he accepted the award

Dave Chappelle with his wife Elaine, arriving at the ceremony

He’s also been criticized for defending fellow comedy Louis CK, who was accused of sexual harassment, mocking transgender people, and taking shots at the #MeToo movement.

‘I don’t mind that people get upset,’ he told PBS in July of last year. ‘I learn about a lot of things, you know, just from my critics.’

He explained his comedic philosophy in one of his stand-up appearances last year.

‘I say a lot of mean things. And I don’t say them because they’re mean, I say them because they’re funny. And everything’s funny until it happens to you,’ he said.

Chappelle has won two Emmy Awards and two Grammy Awards for his work and now has another for his shelf.

The Kennedy Center Mark Twain Prize recognizes those who have had an impact on American society in the vein of 19th-century writer Samuel Clemens, who used the pseudonym Mark Twain.

Previous recipients of the include Tina Fey (2010), Will Ferrell (2011), Ellen DeGeneres (2012), Carol Burnett (2013), Jay Leno (2014), Eddie Murphy (2015), Bill Murray (2016), David Letterman (2017), and Julia Louis-Dreyfus (2018).

Taped Sunday night at the Kennedy Center in Washington D.C., the tribute to Chappelle will air nation-wide on PBS on January 7, 2020.
description: Dave Chappelle was awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor Sunday night and Jon Stewart led a profanity-laced tribute to the politically-incorrect comedian.
